project-settings-mac-environment-questio: For macOS, do you need to add directories to the PATH or define other environment variables for Docker/Podman or Kubernetes?
project-settings-mac-environment-answer-: On macOS, applications started from the Launchpad, Dock, Finder, and Spotlight do not inherit the user's environment.  As such, this application may not have the environment necessary to invoke Docker/Podman, kubectl, and Helm.  Use this section to add extra directories to the PATH and define the extra environment variables needed.  Please note that this extra environment configuration is only used when invoking Docker/Podman, kubectl, and Helm.

project-settings-domain-location-dii-lab: Created as part of the image

project-settings-domain-location-mii-mes: The WebLogic Kubernetes Operator creates the domain in the container used to represent the Administration Server.
project-settings-domain-location-dii-mes: The WebLogic Image Tool creates the domain inside the image during the image creation process.
project-settings-domain-location-pv-mess: In WebLogic Kubernetes Operator versions prior to 4.1.0, the target domain must already exist in a Kubernetes Persistent Volume that is accessible to the target Kubernetes cluster. Because no new domain is being created, there is no need to have a model.  Starting in version 4.1.0, WebLogic Kubernetes Operator can initialize the domain on the Kubernetes Persistent Volume, if desired.  In this case, a domain creation image containing a model will be required.

project-settings-credential-store-policy: How should the project's credentials be stored for this project?
Specifies if and how credentials will be stored for the project.

The Credential Store Policy controls how credentials are handled when the project is saved and loaded.  The options are to store them in the project file encrypted with a passphrase or not store them at all.

Whether you want to specify authentication credentials for pulling the domain creation image from the registry.

Whether you want to use an existing image pull secret or create a new one for pulling the domain creation image.

domain-design-domain-creation-image-wait: Whether WebLogic Kubernetes Operator should wait for the Persistent Volume Claim to be bound before proceeding with domain creation.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-run-: Run RCU as part of domain creation

Whether WebLogic Kubernetes Operator should run the Repository Creation Utility (RCU) as part of creating the initial domain.  If turned off, the RCU schemas specified in the model must already exist.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-wall: The password to use when extracting the OPSS wallet from the newly created domain.
The name of the secret where the OPSS Wallet Password will be stored.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-crea: Create the Kubernetes Persistent Volume Claim (PVC)

Whether WebLogic Kubernetes Operator should create the Kubernetes Persistent Volume Claim (PVC) needed for creating the initial domain.  If turned off, the PVC must exist and be referenced by name using the Persistent Volume Claim Name field in the Volume Configuration section of this page.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pvc-: The name of the Kubernetes Persistent Volume Claim to create.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-use-: Use Default Storage Class for Kubernetes Cluster

Whether to omit the storage class name from the PVC and PV specification.  If selected, the Kubernetes cluster administrator must have configured a default storage class that meets the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator requirements.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pvc-: The name of the storage class to use for the PVC and PV specification.  If left blank, the field will be set to an empty string.  When creating a Persistent Volume with NFS or Host Path, storage class should be left blank so that it is set to an empty string in the PVC.
The amount of storage being requested for this Persistent Volume Claim.
The maximum amount of storage for this Persistent Volume Claim.  If empty, no limit will be specified.
The name of the Kubernetes Persistent Volume to use.  This name must match with the name of an existing Kubernetes Persistent Volume using the same storage class.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-crea: Whether WebLogic Kubernetes Operator should create the Kubernetes Persistent Volume (PV) needed for creating the initial domain.  If turned off, the PV must either exist or be dynamically created by the Persistent Volume Claim.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pv-n: The name of the Kubernetes Persistent Volume to create.  To edit this name, edit the PVC Persistent Volume Name field in the Initialize Persistent Volume Claim Configuration section.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pv-t: The type of persistent volume to create.  Storage Class will use the specified storage class to provision the PV.  NFS and Host Path will set up a persistent volume using already available resources.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pv-r: What happens to the Persistent Volume when released from its claim.  Retain is the default for manually created PVs and Delete is the default for dynamically provisioned PVs.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pv-s: The name of the storage class to use for dynamically provisioning the PV.  To edit this field, edit the Storage Class Name field in the Initialize Persistent Volume Claim Configuration section.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pv-c: The storage capacity of the PV to allocate.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pv-n: The hostname or IP address of the NFS server to use.
The path to the volume on the NFS server.
domain-design-domain-creation-image-pv-h: The path to the volume on the host.

After undeploying the WebLogic domain {{name}}, would you like to also delete the Kubernetes namespace {{namespace}} (and all of its data)?

Undeploying the WebLogic domain will remove the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator's domain custom resource {{domainUid}} and will cause any running pods associated with the domain to be shut down and removed.  Removing the WebLogic domain's namespace {{domainNamespace}} will remove all secrets, config maps, ingress routes, and other Kubernetes objects that exist in the Kubernetes namespace.

quickstart-dialog-stop-showing-quickstar: Stop showing this introduction at startup.
quickstart-page1-paragraph-1: Ready to get your WebLogic Server domain running in Kubernetes?
quickstart-page1-paragraph-2: This application will guide you through the process of creating a WebLogic Server domain in Kubernetes.
quickstart-page1-list-item-1: This is a native application with its own native application menus.
quickstart-page1-list-item-2: The application is broken out by sections: Model, Image, and Kubernetes. Use the left side navigation pane to switch between these sections.
quickstart-page1-list-item-3: Most sections provide a Design View and Code View page.  Design View is intended to simplify project configuration while Code View shows you the code.
quickstart-page1-list-item-4: Sections contain actions that perform work using external tools, like the WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit (WebLogic Kubernetes Operator, WebLogic Deploy Tooling, or WebLogic Image Tool), and other container-related tools (docker/podman, kubectl, and Helm).
quickstart-page2-list-heading: The WKT UI application relies on Internet access for:
quickstart-page2-list-item-1: Downloading style sheets and fonts from the nearest Oracle CDN location.
quickstart-page2-list-item-2: Initializing certain section configuration fields' default values.
quickstart-page2-list-item-3: Checking GitHub for application updates and WKT tool installers.
quickstart-page2-list-item-4: Accessing Docker Hub, GitHub Container Registry, and any other remote Image registries the project specifies.
quickstart-page2-list-item-5: Accessing any remote Kubernetes cluster the project configuration specifies.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-1: As such, it is critical that you review the application preferences to make sure that the Proxy Configuration is correct for your environment.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-2: To access the application preferences, use the Preferences menu item, which is located in the File menu on Windows and Linux and in the application menu on macOS.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-3: Should you have to change the Proxy Configuration, restart the application to make sure the application provides you all the help possible for the default values.
quickstart-page3-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application uses a project file to store user input.
quickstart-page3-list1-heading: Projects are created in two ways:
quickstart-page3-list1-item-1: Explicitly - By using the File menu's New Project menu item.
quickstart-page3-list1-item-2: Implicitly - By working in the application and performing an action that requires saving the project.
quickstart-page3-list2-heading: Important things to understand about the WKT UI project file:
quickstart-page3-list2-item-1: The file is in JSON format and must have a .wktproj file extension.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-2: Only fields with non-default values are saved in the file.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-3: The file only stores references to the WDT model-related files.  While the files are generally treated as part of the project, they are always stored in their WDT files.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-4: Credential fields are never stored in clear text.  They may be encryoted and stored in the project file, or not stored at all.
quickstart-page3-paragraph-2: The WKT UI application uses a one project per window paradigm.  If you try to open the same project file more than once, the application will simply bring the existing window into focus to prevent corruption of the file.
quickstart-page4-list1-heading: The Project Settings section defines key configuration values used throughout the application.  These include:
quickstart-page4-list1-item-2: Where to create the WebLogic Server domain relative to the image.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-3: What is the WebLogic Deploy Tooling target type that most closely matches your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-4: Which Java Home and Oracle Home directories to use for running the WKT tools.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-5: Which image build tool to use--Docker or podman.
quickstart-page4-list2-heading: Where you store the credentials affects sharing of the project file; the options are:
quickstart-page4-list2-item-1: Storing the passphrase-encrypted credentials in the WKT project file means that you have to know the passphrase needed to decrypt the credentials.
quickstart-page4-list2-item-2: Not storing the credentials means that you need to re-enter credentials whenever the project file is opened.
quickstart-page4-list3-heading: Where you store the domain affects the life cycle of the domain; the options are:
quickstart-page4-list3-item-1: Storing the model of the domain in the image. WebLogic Kubernetes Operator creates the domain inside the containers started from the image.
quickstart-page4-list3-item-2: Storing the domain in the image. WebLogic Image Tool creates the domain while it is creating the image.
quickstart-page4-list3-item-3: Storing the domain in a Kubernetes persistent volume. The persistent volume and domain are created outside of this application and WebLogic Kubernetes Operator attaches the persistent volume to the domain's containers.
quickstart-page5-paragraph-1: WebLogic Deploy Tooling (WDT) defines a metadata model for describing a WebLogic Server domain.
quickstart-page5-list1-heading: This metadata model consists of three components:
quickstart-page5-list1-item-2: Variables - Defines a set of tokens to be used in the model and their values.
quickstart-page5-list1-item-3: Archive - Contains application-related and domain-related files and directories to be added to the domain.
quickstart-page5-paragraph-2: For more information, please see the documentation:
quickstart-page5-list2-heading: The WKT UI application supports creating, discovering, importing, and editing WDT metadata models.
quickstart-page5-list2-item-1: Use the File menu's Add Model menu to discover a model from a domain or import existing model files.
quickstart-page5-list2-item-2: Use the Model section to create new or edit existing model-related files.
quickstart-page6-list-heading: The Model Design View page allows the WebLogic Remote Console {{wrcVersion}} to provide a familiar graphical interface for viewing and editing the model-related files.
quickstart-page6-list-item-1: On the left side is the Navigation bar that supports navigating into different areas of the model.
quickstart-page6-list-item-2: The right side shows the model content for the selected part of the model to add, remove, or edit model objects and values.
quickstart-page6-list-item-3: Above the right side model content, the Search Model control provides access to the WebLogic Remote Console search functionality for locating objects in the model.
quickstart-page6-paragraph-1: In the action button bar, the Prepare Model button (or the Go menu item) optimizes the model for Kubernetes deployment.
quickstart-page6-paragraph-2: When running certain actions, such as Prepare Model, the collapsed Console panel automatically appears and displays the stdout and stderr streams.
quickstart-page7-list-heading: The Model Code View page provides three panes that support viewing and editing the model-related files.
quickstart-page7-list-item-1: On the left side is the Model Editor that supports editing the model.
quickstart-page7-list-item-2: In the upper right is the Variable Editor that supports adding, removing, and updating variable names and their values.
quickstart-page7-list-item-3: In the lower right is the Archive Editor that supports adding, removing, and updating files and directories in the archive.
quickstart-page7-paragraph-1: In the action button bar, the Validate Model button (or the Go menu item) supports validating the model to ensure that it is syntactically correct.  This is particularly valuable when editing the model in the Model Code View.
quickstart-page8-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application supports creating a suitable Linux image for deploying your WebLogic Server-based domain.
quickstart-page8-list1-heading: When creating an image, you need to specify which:
quickstart-page8-list1-item-1: Image Tag to apply to the new image.
quickstart-page8-list1-item-2: Image Registry Push credentials to use to push the image to the registry specified in the Image Tag.
quickstart-page8-paragraph-2: The collapsible Advanced section provides access to other configuration that might be required in your environment.
quickstart-page8-list2-heading: Patching the Oracle Fusion Middleware installation is optional but strongly recommended. The application allows you to get:
quickstart-page8-list2-item-1: All Recommended Patches (which includes the latest PSU).
quickstart-page8-paragraph-3: All patches will be downloaded automatically using your Oracle Support user name and password.
quickstart-page9-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application requires the Kubernetes client tool kubectl to be properly configured to connect to your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page9-list-heading: This section of the application helps you configure kubectl to be able to connect to your cluster:
quickstart-page9-list-item-1: Select the Kubernetes cluster provider type to see instructions for configuring kubectl for your cluster.
quickstart-page9-list-item-2: After configuring kubectl using the provided instructions, specify the correct values for the configuration properties in the section.
quickstart-page9-list-item-3: Use the Verify Connectivity action to make sure the application is able to connect to the cluster.
quickstart-page10-paragraph-1: When using the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator as the WDT target type, the following sections will be shown.
quickstart-page10-list2-heading: This section makes it easy to install the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator into your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page10-list2-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects and Helm chart value overrides.
quickstart-page10-list2-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation.
quickstart-page10-list2-item-3: The Install Operator button (and Go menu item) performs the necessary actions to install the operator.
quickstart-page10-list3-heading: This section makes it easy to deploy the Kubernetes objects needed by the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator to deploy the domain and start the servers.
quickstart-page10-list3-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects, including model variable override values and secret values.
quickstart-page10-list3-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation as well as the YAML resource definitions.
quickstart-page10-list3-item-3: The Deploy Domain button (and Go menu item) performs the necessary actions to deploy the Kubernetes objects required by the operator.
quickstart-page10-list3-item-4: The Get Domain Status button (and Go menu item) queries the Kubernetes cluster to determine the status of the last domain deployment action.
quickstart-page10-list4-heading: This section makes it easy to expose your domain's endpoint outside the cluster, as well as to install an ingress controller.
quickstart-page10-list4-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects and Helm chart value overrides.
quickstart-page10-list4-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation as well as the YAML resource definitions.
quickstart-page10-list4-item-3: The Install Ingress Controller and Update Ingress Routing buttons (and Go menu items) perform the necessary actions to install the ingress controller and update routes on an existing ingress controller.
